translation.title: The Finest Lady in the Land

segments.en: Linked Discourses 47
2. At Nālandā
20. The Finest Lady in the Land
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sumbhesu viharati sedakaṃ nāma sumbhānaṃ nigamo.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sumbhas, near the town of the Sumbhas called Sedaka.
There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
“Mendicants!”
“Venerable sir,” they replied.
The Buddha said this:

segments.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ‘janapadakalyāṇī, janapadakalyāṇī’ti kho, bhikkhave, mahājanakāyo sannipateyya.
segments.en: “Mendicants, suppose that on hearing, ‘The finest lady in the land! The finest lady in the land!’ a large crowd would gather.

segments.pli: ‘Sā kho panassa janapadakalyāṇī paramapāsāvinī nacce, paramapāsāvinī gīte.
segments.en: And the finest lady in the land would dance and sing in a most thrilling way.

segments.pli: Janapadakalyāṇī naccati gāyatī’ti kho, bhikkhave, bhiyyoso mattāya mahājanakāyo sannipateyya.
segments.en: On hearing, ‘The finest lady in the land is dancing and singing! The finest lady in the land is dancing and singing!’ an even larger crowd would gather.

segments.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhappaṭikūlo.
segments.en: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.
They’d say to him,

segments.pli: ‘ayaṃ te, ambho purisa, samatittiko telapatto antarena ca mahāsamajjaṃ antarena ca janapadakalyāṇiyā pariharitabbo.
segments.en: ‘Mister, this is a bowl full to the brim with oil. You must carry it in between this large crowd and the finest lady in the land.

segments.pli: Puriso ca te ukkhittāsiko piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhissati.
segments.en: And a man with a drawn sword will follow behind you.

segments.pli: Yattheva naṃ thokampi chaḍḍessati tattheva te siro pātessatī’ti.
segments.en: Wherever you spill even a drop, he’ll chop off your head right there.’
What do you think, mendicants?

segments.pli: api nu so puriso amuṃ telapattaṃ amanasikaritvā bahiddhā pamādaṃ āhareyyā”ti?
segments.en: Would that person lose focus on that bowl, and negligently get distracted outside?”
“No, sir.”

segments.pli: “Upamā kho myāyaṃ, bhikkhave, katā atthassa viññāpanāya.
segments.en: “I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
And this is what it means.

segments.pli: samatittiko telapattoti kho, bhikkhave, kāyagatāya etaṃ satiyā adhivacanaṃ.
segments.en: ‘A bowl of oil filled to the brim’ is a term for mindfulness of the body.
So you should train like this:

segments.pli: ‘kāyagatā sati no bhāvitā bhavissati bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā’ti.
segments.en: ‘We will develop mindfulness of the body. We’ll cultivate it, make it our vehicle and our basis, keep it up, consolidate it, and properly implement it.’
That’s how you should train.”

suttaplex.blurb: A parable that sets up an impossible challenge: to walk between a popular performer and the crowd jostling to see her, carrying a bowl of oil filled to the brim, while a man with a drawn sword waits to chop off your head if you spill a drop. That’s mindfulness!
